description: The ex-Coral guitarist follows a heavily orchestral debut solo album with this lower stakes collection of autobiographical anecdotes, recorded in his boyhood bedroom and produced by Simian Mobile Disco's James Ford.

title: Moody Coup
label: Software
description: The second album from Baltimore's Co La represents a compositional step up from 2011's Daydream Repeater, smoothing the seams between his heavy sampling and original music-- provided in part by ex-Dirty Projector Angel Deradoorian on vocals.

title: New History Warfare Vol. 3: To See More Light
label: Constellation
description: The sprawling closing chapter of Colin Stetson's New History Warfare trilogy adds a welcome wrinkle in the vocals of Bon Iver's Justin Vernon-- sometimes angelic, sometimes metal brutal-- and sees the Montreal-based saxophonist explore extremes of darkness and light.

title: Acid Rap
label: Unknown
description: Barely out of his teens, Chancelor Bennett has transformed himself from a suspended high school student to a much adored Chicago rapper. His second mixtape, Acid Rap, invites elements of classic soul, juke, gospel, blues-rock, drill, acid jazz, house, ragtime scat, and R. Kelly, Twista, and a young Kanye to the same open mic poetry night.

title: Thank You for Letting Me Be Myself
label: FXHE
description: The Detroit producer's third proper album is a love letter to a few things Omar pretends not to care about: his fans, his hometown, and house music. Here, he berates us with kindness, offering wistful, major-key tracks out of step with his reputation for hissy lo-fi concoctions.

title: Teethed Glory and Injury
label: Profound Lore
description: The third LP from Altar of Plagues is a dense, demanding record where black metal slams against industrial throb, and noise sheets work alongside diaphanous electronics. It suggests the heyday of Touch and Go, Nine Inch Nails in their prime, or Swans at their vitrolic apex.

title: Praxis Makes Perfect
label: Lex
description: Super Furry Animals' Gruff Rhys and Bryan Hollon (aka Boom Bip) continue their pursuit of the album-biopic by dedicating Neon Neon's second full-length to the life of Giangiacomo Feltrinelli, a wealthy Italian scion turned left-wing political activist and publisher, to the tune of deceptively plasticized synth pop.

title: Songs Cycled
label: Bella Union
description: Van Dyke Parks' Songs Cycled collects six 7" singles he's released over the past few years. A lot of what's here has appeared before, elsewhere and in different forms, and then there's the traditional music that belongs to nobody. Like all his albums, it's cheerful and maddeningly detailed.

title: Silence Yourself
label: Matador
description: Silence Yourself is one of rock’s most commanding and ferociously poised debuts in recent years, the work of a new band with an outsized confidence and sharp clarity of vision.

title: Discipline + Desire
label: Slumberland
description: The San Francisco goth-pop band Wax Idols' second album Discipline & Desire is aloof and commanding, with an expertly honed sense of how far to take the tension it builds before offering relief.

title: Master, We Perish
label: At a Loss
description: Over the past few years, the Body have gone through several personnel changes, and moved from Providence, RI, to Portland, OR. The time spent in flux has only galvanized the now-duo's central focus: sounding completely terrifying, in an Armageddon-with-a-view, end-of-everything manner.

title: Prisoner of Conscious
label: Blacksmith
description: For Talib Kweli, songs like "Definition" and "Get By" still deserve all the adulation they inspire. However, on his new Prisoner of Conscious, the 37-year-old founding father of conscious-rap is now acknowledging his own antiquity.

title: Blowout
label: Shea Stadium
description: The Brooklyn-based DIY punk band's new full-length is clever without being cheeky, sincere without being preachy, self-aware but never too in on their own joke.

title: Monomania
label: 4AD
description: On Deerhunter’s swaggering fifth album, Monomania, they almost completely jettison the dreamy ambience that usually characterizes their work in favor of straight-up raw, bleeding garage rock, populating the songs with junkyards, leather jackets, and motorcycles.

title: Private Airplane
label: Anyway
description: Connections' debut album bears an obvious debt to fellow Ohians Guided By Voices' Bee Thousand, but as Columbus lifers (their drummer was in Times New Viking) they get away with it, offering as good a pass at 90s-style guitar rock as you're likely to get outside of the decade.

title: Eglo Records Vol. 1
label: Eglo
description: Alex Rogers and Sam Shepherd's Eglo Records emerged in 2009 and has since functioned as a bridge between the increasingly fragmented identity of London's dancefloors and global currents in contemporary soul. Eglo Records Volume I is their largest project to date and functions as a consolidation of the successes of those early years.

title: Ghosts Go Blind
label: Western Vinyl
description: David Wingo's third album as Ola Podrida puts his role as a composer for film in the shade, proving an abruptly extroverted and thoroughly satisfying record that thrives on the vigorous execution of some familiar, genre-specific sounds: think the Clientele, Interpol, and even Coldplay.

title: Everybody Loves Sausages
label: Ipecac
description: The covers album Everybody Loves Sausages is a tour through the Melvin's most beloved songs, hitting most of the expected bases (Venom, Throbbing Gristle) with a few surprises (Queen, Roxy Music). Mudoney's Mark Arm, Jello Biafra, Neurosis' Scott Kelly, J.G. Thirwell, Clem Burke of Blondie, and others, offer guest vocals.

title: MCII
label: Merge
description: On Mikal Cronin's first album for Merge, the Ty Segall collaborator balances the "power" and "pop" elements of his sound with aplomb, while sounding utterly out of sync internally. It's pop poetry for the aloof, and Cronin's most fully realized, beautifully arranged, well-crafted work to date.

title: Fabric 69
label: Fabric
description: Darkness reigned supreme for influential techno label/collective Sandwell District, which shuttered its operations in 2012. This sprawling, lavish 75-minute Fabric 69 mix, the first release in two years to bear the SD name, isn't meant to signal a new beginning for the collective as much as it's a menacing, immersive summation.

title: Alone in the Grave
label: 20 Buck Spin
description: The Olympia, WA, band Bone Sickness understand the link between death metal and punk, and their 18-minute debut LP Alone in the Grave finds them exerting themselves strongly in a crowded death metal landscape.

title: TRAXX: The House That Garage Built
label: Need Want
description: Traxx: The House That Garage Built does a decent job of rounding up a representative collection of bona fide garage revival anthems by the likes of Dusky, Ejeca, and Disclosure, but the real treasures are its most idiosyncratic, least authentic inclusions.

title: Sub Verses
label: Dead Oceans
description: Akron/Family's seventh album is heavy on the anthems but also reveals Akron/Family as a surprisingly typical rock troupe that rallies around cutting guitar figures and frenzied drum work.

title: English Little League
label: Fire
description: English Little League is Guided by Voices' fourth LP since their comeback, meaning they've now made as many post-hiatus LPs as they managed during their "classic era." Amidst the booming arena-rockers, swift power-pop, proggy bluster, and wads of bubblegum, it marks the first appearance of recordings from Bob Pollard's new home-studio.

title: Golden Rules for Golden People
label: Equal Vision
description: The Boston trio follow 2008's Hardly Art-backed second album with a collection that mines DIY values through the sounds of vintage surf-rock, orchestral pop, and power-pop. The crazy feel of their earlier work remains, but it’s accompanied by the kitchen sink.

title: Manégarmr
label: Southern Lord
description: The Belgian band Hessian's Southern Lord debut moves between black metal wails and head-down hardcore wallop, between narcotic instrumental drift and dense full-band efficiency, while always returning to an assured stylistic center.

title: Live in Concert
label: Rostrum
description: The Live in Concert studio collaboration between Wiz Khalifa and Curren$y was held up for some time because of sample clearance issues; in that respect it was worth the wait, as the jazzy production has much to recommend.

title: Perils from the Sea
label: Caldo Verde
description: Mark Kozelek turns over all non-vocal responsibilities to the Album Leaf's Jimmy Lavalle on this collaboration, setting his ruminations on memory to Lavalle's subtle electronic pulses. The effect underscores Kozelek's lyrics with a new and more urgent desperation.

title: Thr!!!er
label: Warp
description: Thirteen years and five LPs into !!!'s output, the mostly well-turned but low-impact Thr!!!er has all the hallmarks of the Brooklyn punk-funk band-- wiry, kinked guitars, ropy bass lines, popping handclaps, chanting choruses, and falsetto outbursts-- minus a crucial one: abandon.

title: Bigfoot
label: Secretly Canadian
description: The debut album from Santa Monica's Zach Yudin trades in breezy, hooky tropical pop that owes a great debt to Vampire Weekend's first record, and mostly concerns Yudin's West Coast lifestyle: that's beaches, parties, and girls.

title: Wheel
label: Don Giovanni
description: Punk-turned-country-leaning chronicler Laura Stevenson’s third album is her first with an outside producer, Kevin McMahon, who's previously worked with Titus Andronicus and Swans. It's also the first where she's decided to deal with her demons.

title: Cloud Room, Glass Room
label: Kranky
description: It's been four years since the last album, the ambient leaning White Bird Release, from Mark Nelson's Pan American project*.* If that record was all long, wintery shadows, the band's new album Cloud Room, Glass Room brings in a touch of warmth from their earlier recordings.

title: Acrobatic Tenement / Relationship of Command
label: Twenty-First Chapter
description: At the Drive-In stuck around long enough to have an unequivocal impact and burned out before they could wear out their welcome. Now, without much fanfare, the charismatic El Paso post-hardcore band are reissuing their 1996 debut Acrobatic Tenement and their 2000 swan song Relationship of Command.

title: Ready to Die
label: Fat Possum
description: The Stooges' fifth album Ready to Die avoids the pitfalls of 2007's disastrous reunion album The Weirdness, but 40 years removed from the kamikaze death-trip fantasies of Raw Power, it's the sound of Iggy admitting, “I’m too old for this shit.”

title: 13 Degrees of Reality
label: Now Again
description: The Heliocentrics' 2007 debut Out There still sounds good six years later-- largely because it would've sounded good 40 years prior. Their new album 13 Degrees of Reality finds another angle: a nervous, conspiracy-minded anxiety.

title: Withdrawal
label: Candlelight
description: Mixing hardcore, black metal, and thrash, the Brooklyn-via-Philadelphia quartet Woe's excellent, ambitious Withdrawal is an unforgiving record with an unbroken focus. The intricacy of the band's music-- and there’s plenty of it-- doesn’t interfere with its immediacy.

title: Sister Faith
label: Temporary Residence
description: The Louisville punk trio Coliseum's J Robbins-produced fourth album covers the inevitability of death, the absurdity of faith, and what it means to be alive when everything ends. But it's also fun: In terms of pure chugging rock'n'roll, it sits comfortably next to Torche and Baroness.

title: ½ Gentlemen / Not Beasts
label: Fire
description: Fire Records' 4xLP reissue of Half Japanese's ½ Gentlemen / Not Beasts demonstrates how the Fair brothers' caveman racket anticipated the work of acts such as Daniel Johnston and Beat Happening; it's a brilliant mix of loud punk blasts, shapeless rants, heartfelt confessions, and minimal experiments.

title: Oblivion OST
label: Back Lot
description: In 2010, Daft Punk teamed up with composer and arranger Joseph Trapanese to score a reboot of the classic sci-fi movie Tron*.* Three years later, M83's Anthony Gonzalez has paired with Trapanese to score another sci-fi extravaganza, the Joseph Kosinski-directed Oblivion.

title: Baba Yaga
label: Fat Possum
description: The Athens-based cosmic country band Futurebirds' second full-length nails the melancholy of trying to chase and pin down something that's special and fleeting. It does so with a loose-limbed tangle of reverbed guitars, hollered harmonies, and driving Southern rock rhythms.

title: The Great Perhaps
label: Rough Trade
description: UK duo The Boy Least Likely To have emerged as a beacon of stability within the tumultuous confines of the indie pop world. The best moments on their new album revolve around the band's deployment of a previously unheard influence or instrument.

title: To Be Close to You
label: Birdtapes
description: The hushed and lovely Maryland indie pop outfit's first official release was recorded straight to tape, and the resulting sound world is a reward in itself for hardcore cassette fans. These are warm, reassuring-- if mordant-- songs that recall Elliott Smith, or K Records-era Modest Mouse.

title: Ultramarine
label: Paper Bag
description: Studio's Dan Lissvik once again produces for the Canadian starburst electro-pop band, rendering their fluroescent synths and Balearic rhythms clean without being clinical, and making their heady, romantic, high stakes lyrical world three-dimensional.

title: True Romance
label: IAMSOUND
description: After some big early singles and some unsteady mixtapes, Charlotte Aitchison's debut album delievers on that initial promise. True Romance is an album of emotionally direct, bubblegum-catchy, off-kilter songs about falling in and out of love.

title: Young, Gifted & Yellow
label: VP
description: This new collection on VP Records provides a 40-song introduction to the legendary dancehall vocalist's influential career, stretching back to his early 1980s singles.

title: II
label: Sacred Bones
description: Föllakzoid hail from Santiago, Chile. But with their rigid rhythms, their chemtrail synths, their afterburner guitars, their sound is pure Düsseldorf, circa 1971. And this krautrock-worshiping quartet's fascination with all things kosmische isn't merely musical.

title: Anika EP
label: Stones Throw
description: The majority of English/German singer Annika Henderson’s releases to date have comprised dank covers of pop and folk songs with BEAK> as her backing band. Her newest in this vein features her takes on the Kinks, Chromatics, the Crystals, Yoko Ono, and Shocking Blue, as well as a dub version of an original.

title: Wait to Pleasure
label: Mexican Summer
description: The Montreal shoegaze band display far more confidence on their second album than on any of their previous releases, breaking out of the murk to offer distinct, tactile sensations in the form of glam rock stomp, slo-mo pop, desert blues, and dirty electroclash. Somehow, it all fits.

title: Reincarnated
label: RCA
description: Snoop Dogg's dalliance with reggae was documented in the film Reincarnated and this is the companion album. Snoop's leaden vocalizing and dreadful fake patois are occasionally saved by the strong production from Major Lazer, Vybz Kartel collaborator Dre Skull, and producer/songwriter Ariel Rechtshaid.

title: Heart of Oak
label: Season of Mist
description: Vancouver metal quartet Anciients' debut album is as excessive as that second "i" in their name, but they compensate for excess with excitement, playing with the hookiness of Baroness and the warm sticky riffs of Torche.

title: Blues Trip
label: Blackout Beach
description: Frog Eyes leader Carey Mercer's newest album as Blackout Beach reimagines seven songs from his 2011 synth-based collection Fuck Death. It's a more traditional rock record featuring ex-Wolf Parade member Dante Decaro, Frog Eyes drummer Melanie Campbell, and Destroyer's Dan Bejar.

title: Illumination Ritual
label: Graveface
description: The nocturnal, comforting Illumination Ritual offers up a definitive portrait of the Appleseed Cast, a record that can serve as an entryway to the post-rock/emo band's sprawling discography as well as a culmination of it.

title: King Remembered In Time
label: Def Jam
description: Big K.R.I.T.'s new tape King Remembered in Time doesn’t try to deliver on the promise of his breakthrough mixtape Return of 4eva. Instead, it sounds sounds more like a checkpoint halfway between where he’s been and where he wants to go.

title: Junip
label: Mute
description: The Jose Gonzalez-fronted trio's self-titled follow-up to their 2010 debut LP is ambitious in its details, with Tobias Winterkorn's synths and keyboards not only defining the atmosphere of the album, but usually determining the structure of the songs.

title: Bored Nothing
label: Spunk
description: Fergus Miller, aka Bored Nothing, wrote these songs while bumming semi-homeless around Australia, and the characters in his songs are perpetually stoned, bored, or existentially lost. It's familiar territory, but Miller has a way with words and a refreshing clear-eyed honesty.

title: Chunky Monkey
label: Hippos in Tanks
description: On New York-based sound designer Aaron David Ross' Chunky Monkey, there's palpable sense of excitement to each track, a feeling of someone thinking about everything they've ever been influenced by and trying to cram it all into a four-minute dash to the finish line-- smoky 80s cocktail jazz butting up against jungle drums and loping reggae basslines.

title: V
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Between September 2009 and September 2011, Barn Owl's Evan Caminiti and Jon Porras released four full-length albums, and several collaborative and solo LPs. After a release-free 2012, their return sees the pair augment their guitars with keyboard drones, digital rhythms, and kaleidoscopic synth hues.

title: Grownass Man
label: Middle West
description: Bon Iver's Justin Vernon reunites with long-time friends Phil Cook of (Megafaun, DeYarmond Edison) and Brian Moen (Peter Wolf Crier, Laarks) for a low-stakes record of bar-band blues and raspy blue-eyed soul.

title: Bankrupt!
label: Glassnote
description: The French foursome's fifth album scans as a post-success commentary, dropping you into a fast-changing world of K-pop synth melodies, Californian glamor and Scandinavian leather where they appear distinctly uncomfortable. The only reliable constant is the band's winning, shiny, jacked-up formula.

title: Gordian
label: 50 Weapons
description: As Cosmin TRG, bass music auteur Cosmin Nicolae made spare but spaced-out tech house on 2011's Simulat. With his new album, Gordian, Nicolae's gone from evolution to refinement, a paring down that feels like it's wringing every last idea out of the musical concepts he set into motion on his previous album.

title: VHÖL
label: Profound Lore
description: This West Coast metal quartet features members of Yob, Ludicra, and Hammers of Misfortune. Their self-titled debut is a wonderfully weird intersection of black metal and hardcore impulse and attitude, laced with prog, thrash, and gloriously old-school rock'n'roll.

title: Rat Farm
label: Megaforce
description: From the spluttering hardcore of their first LP through wildcard bassist Cris Kirkwood's lost years, the Meat Puppets seemed to chase chaos, musical and otherwise. On their 14th album, they opt more for a leisurely drive down a familiar track.

title: RockaByeBaby
label: Interscope
description: The R&B singer with a growing cult fanbase releases a free mixtape that finds her supremely confident and demonstrating a remarkable range. Guests include Fabolous, French Montana, Meek Mill, and more.

title: Ghost on Ghost
label: Nonesuch
description: Sam Beam's sixth Iron & Wine album Ghost on Ghost is packed with ideas and features musical flourishes that nod to 1970s lite rock, jazz, and the blues.

title: Snapper EP
label: Flying Nun
description: The New Zealand band Snapper's 1988 debut EP is surfacing again via a limited edition Record Store Day release as part of Captured Tracks' reissue campaign for the Flying Nun catalog. The organ-droning kraut-pop collection deserves a bigger audience.

title: A Quiet Darkness
label: Downtown
description: Dexter Tortoriello and Megan Messina's debut album as Houses was a chillwave-y collection about their time hiding out from reality and living off the land in Hawaii. Its follow-up is a drifty, ambient concept album (in name only) about a couple separated by a nuclear holocaust and trying to reunite.

title: Live
label: Delicacies
description: Simian Mobile Disco perform with a series of analogue synths, a 909 drum machine, and effects pedals, and their live show exhibits a deep understanding of tension and release. Live is a one-take, unedited recording of their gig at the Philadelphia show of their summer 2012 U.S. tour.

title: Infestissumam
label: Loma Vista
description: Over the last few years, the mysterious, much-hyped Swedish band formerly known as Ghost have cultivated an alluring persona of subversion and symbolism. Infestissumam, their first album for a major label, follows their 2010 debut Opus Eponymous, a collection of old-school "Satanic" heavy metal with hooks as addictive as sin.

title: Twelve Reasons to Die
label: Wax Poetics
description: This collaboration between L.A. producer Adrian Younge's soul-steeped live band and Ghostface Killah tells the story of Tony Starks, an enforcer for the DeLuca crime family, who's murdered by his former employers after striking out on his own.

title: Anarchic
label: Flenser
description: The anarchist black metal movement forms a small but fascinating pocket in the extreme metal scene. The Vancouver duo Skagos' Anarchic is a sprawling, four-part composition that fills a double LP with a blend of graceful, shoegazey post-rock and blasts of raw-throated, left-leaning black metal.

title: Alphawaves
label: Thrill Jockey
description: On Alphawaves, Trans Am guitarist Phil Manley, along with drummer Jon Theodore (Mars Volta/Queens of the Stone Age), demonstrates an affinity for reappropriating the core tools of Neu! and other krautrock acts, and for carbon reproductions of various other styles. But this isn't tribute-band trash.

title: The Plain Where the Palace Stood
label: Drag City
description: David Grubbs' latest album sees the Gastr Del Sol founder joined by C. Spencer Yeh on violin, drummer/composer Andrea Belfi, and guitarist Stefano Pilia, who are given generous room to operate within Grubbs' open-ended, elliptical playing style.

title: Top of the Pops
label: The End
description: Art Brut's Top of the Pops is a 2xCD greatest hits collection featuring a disc of B-sides and demos. In the narrative the collection spins, everything that followed the London band's 2005 debut Bang Bang Rock & Roll did so with increasing shades of bitterness.

title: Excavation
label: Tri Angle
description: With Excavation, London-based electronic producer Bobby Krlic, aka the Haxan Cloak, offers a multifaceted roadmap of the afterlife. The record, his first for Tri Angle, is about the journey taken after death, and it's bold and domineering, the kind of music that towers over you and casts a giant, intimidating shadow.

title: Kone EP
label: self-released
description: The Chicago band amicably parted ways with Sonic Youth's Steve Shelley after the release of 2012's Pre Language. This tougher, noisier three-song EP is far more compelling than anything from that full-length.

title: New York Renaissance
label: self-released
description: Hot 97 DJ Peter Rosenberg has become both a champion and a patron of the kind of rap he loves while demonizing music that doesn’t fit into the parameters he’s set. The new mixtape New York Renaissance, which Rosenberg commissioned, sounds exactly how you would expect it to sound.

title: Desperate Ground
label: Saddle Creek
description: After the more introspective tone of 2010’s Personal Life, Desperate Ground superficially evokes the Portland trio’s incendiary earlier work, speaking the same vocabulary as 2006’s high watermark, The Body, The Blood, The Machine.

title: Inspiration Information / Wings of Love
label: Epic / Legacy
description: This 2xCD reissue of brilliant, reclusive L.A. songwriter Shuggie Otis' 1974 masterwork Inspiration Information includes four extra tracks from that session along with Wings of Love, comprising 14 tracks that Otis recorded between 1975 and 2000. Combined, the collections feel like a parallel universe greatest-hits compilation, from a world where a label embraced Otis’s genius and eccentricity, instead of driving him away.

title: Free the Universe
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Diplo's globally-minded dancehall fusion project soliders on without Switch and Skerrit Bwoy. This time out, there's a very long list of guests including Ezra Koenig, Wyclef Jean, Santigold, Tyga, Shaggy, Amber Coffman, and many more.

title: Reflection of the Negative
label: Relapse
description: Later this year, Relapse will issue LPs from Richmond, Va., doom acts Cough and Windhand. The two groups have released their best music to date on Reflection of the Negative, an immersive split EP that serves as an important notice for Richmond as a center for metal in the United States.

title: Rituals
label: wSphere
description: Nicolas Fromageau founded M83 with Anthony Gonzalez in 2001, recording second album Dead Cities, Red Seas & Lost Ghosts before departing in 2004. The debut LP from his new group, the electronic rock band Team Ghost, is darker and sleazier than his past project.

title: Supermigration
label: Planet Mu
description: For the Irish dance duo's second album, they step out of the bedroom and into a professional studio, allowing them to pursue their pop muse with renewed fervor.

title: Floating Coffin
label: Castle Face
description: Continuing Thee Oh Sees' impressive run of the last couple of years, the John Dwyer-fronted garage rock band's newest album is another resounding success. With its dark undertones, and lyrics about splattered blood and dead children, it's also sort of a sadistic success.

title: Mosquito
label: Interscope
description: For the Yeah Yeah Yeahs' fourth album, they returned to the casual creative processes that produced their first demo and electrifying debut album, yet they struggle to recapture their early vitality.

title: The North Borders
label: Ninja Tune
description: UK producer Simon Green, now based in New York, was at the forefront of the downtempo electronica scene that bubbled up in the late 90s and early 2000s. His fifth studio album as Bonobo features guest vocals from Erykah Badu and a haunting sense of déjà vu.

title: The Ol' Soul EP
label: Kidfire
description: The Greenville, S.C., rapper and singer Alpoko Don joined Youtube about a year ago and started uploading his now very popular music videos. The Ol’ Soul EP, a collection of new songs and YouTube favorites, is an arresting rap record, unique in its minimalist sound and bathed in the fingerprints of the South's musical history.

title: FM Sushi
label: Kompakt
description: The colorful Los Angeles dance-pop trio’s second album, released on their Time No Place imprint with help from Kompakt, retains their 2010 debut’s feeling of youthful mischief, but reinforces it with tuneful songs and deluxe production that seemed only a distant possibility on that collection.

title: Way to Blue: The Songs of Nick Drake
label: StorySound
description: Nick Drake's original producer Joe Boyd organized a series of tribute concerts around the world to celebrate the British folk legend. Way to Blue is a companion compilation featuring Robyn Hitchcock, Vashti Bunyan, Scritti Politti's Green Gartside, Lisa Hannigan, and others.

title: Kill Uncle
label: Parlophone
description: Kill Uncle, Morrissey's second solo LP, which has now been reissued with an alternate version of one of its songs, has a largely deserved reputation as his least distinctive. A minor album by a major artist, it still offers its own curious pleasures, particularly for the converted.

title: You Have Already Gone To The Other World
label: LM Dupli-Cation
description: A Hawk and a Hacksaw's kaleidoscopic sixth LP blends clips from Sergei Parajanov's film Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors with centuries-old Ukranian, Hungarian, and Romanian tunes and several new compositions that apply modern flourishes to the band's tradition-minded melodies.

title: Music For Dancefloors: The KPM Music Library
label: Strut
description: It's no surprise that KPM, a label famous for its deep collection of vintage "library music," has provided a rich source of samples over the years: The beats are mixed high, sound crisp, and are delivered with supreme confidence and precision. There's certainly a feeling of joy to much of the music here, but little or no sense of abandon.

title: Beautiful Africa
label: Nonesuch
description: Though Rokia Traoré’s past albums established her as a fine singer, her new Beautiful Africa feels more accomplished than ever, her voice bending around her words (sung mostly in Bamana) with flourishes of subtle vibrato.

title: English Electric
label: BMG
description: Incorporating references to Kraftwerk, Philip Glass's Einstein on the Beach, and their own classic back catalogue, the British new wave band OMD's second album since reforming in 2006 features a tension between the past and a possible way forward.

title: Give Up
label: Sub Pop
description: Ten years after its release and subsequent appearance on so many soundtracks and commercials, the influential debut album by the synth-pop project of Ben Gibbard and Jimmy Tamborello has been reissued. The deluxe set includes remixes and covers by Matthew Dear, the Shins, and others.

title: Birthmarks
label: Yep Roc
description: Birthmarks is the Toronto band's most refined release to date, but at times it smooths over the ragged edges that made Born Ruffians such a rivetingly unpredictable band in the first place.

title: Cyclops Reap
label: Castle Face
description: Tim Presley's latest album as White Fence started as a vault-clearing but wound up consisting almost entirely of new songs. The material exhibits a new clarity and melodic directness, demonstrating Presley's mastery of home recording.

title: Recurring Dream
label: Kranky
description: The Chicago drone-rockers' sophomore LP, Recurring Dream, is a mesmerizing record with a distinctly sinister edge. Even as you're drawn in by its narcotic murk, you can't quite shake the feeling that something terrible's happened that you just can't quite recall.

title: No Answer : Lower Floors
label: De Stijl
description: The vocal-heavy No Answer is  the clearest and most detailed record in Wolf Eyes' vast catalogue. There’s little in the way of buried elements or blurred dissonance; in fact, much of the album could be accurately described as minimal.

title: Wakin on a Pretty Daze
label: Matador
description: Wakin on a Pretty Daze is Kurt Vile's most spacious, becalmed record yet, and it contains some of his best-ever brand of cosmic stand-up. The album moves at its own stately pace and with its own serene logic and time.

title: They're Flowers
label: Western Vinyl
description: Carter Tanton has worked as an engineer with Marissa Nadler and Twin Shadow's George Lewis, Jr., and as a member of Lower Dens; on his second proper solo record, he uses his production acumen to explore texture.

title: For Now I Am Winter
label: Mercury
description: The Icelandic composer who has toured with Sigur Rós delivers an icily beautiful new album that mixes minimalist classical with singer-songwriter material made in collaboration with vocalist Arnór Dan.

title: Make You EP
label: Hotflush
description: If their new EP is any indication, bass duo Sepalcure, which includes Travis Stewart of Machinedrum, are less about growth and more about refinement. Mixing hard-hitting rhythms with pastoral touches and pink-cloud ambience, Sepalcure are still deadly serious about having a good time.

title: Monkey Minds in the Devil's Time
label: Double Six
description: The former Beta Band frontman's new solo album revives some of his former outfit's playful experimentation on songs that veer from deeply intimate to unabashedly political.

title: Overgrown
label: Republic
description: James Blake's follow-up to his breakthrough self-titled album incorporates more gospel and R&B elements and a wider variety of textures. He successfully splits the difference between the sultry bedroom vibes of R&B’s resurgent Quiet Storm moment and the more mundane life of a British “bedroom” artist.

title: From the Ashes of Nuclear Destruction
label: Relapse
description: Portland, Ore.'s, Toxic Holocaust, fronted by the babyfaced Joel Grind, play sleazy thrash with nuclear and Venom fixations. This compilation offers a hodgepodge of rough, primitive, very fun heavy metal dating back to 2003’s Evil Never Dies LP and spanning 15 years of splits, albums, EPs, and rarities.

title: Specter at the Feast
label: Abstract Dragon
description: Black Rebel Motorcycle Club’s sixth studio LP was inspired by the death of Michael Been, the band’s producer/sound technician and father to bassist Robert Levon Been. On it, the San Francisco trio make the transition from classic rock pretenders to full-on classic rock.

title: Ministry of Love
label: IAMSOUND
description: While IO Echo are quick to flaunt kotos and kimonos as signifiers, their anticipated debut's neon-lit reveries and gothic glamour conjure a romantic ideal of their Los Angeles homebase. In nearly all aspects, the bombastic duo arrive fully formed, but it comes at a cost.

title: Cruise Your Illusion
label: Fat Possum
description: Milk Music are a product of the fertile Olympia scene and Cruise Your Illusion finds them pulling influences from post-punk, classic rock, and blues. Lead singer Alex Coxen is a candid lyricist who conveys both piercing emotional vulnerability and confrontational punk swagger.

title: Shaking the Habitual
label: Mute
description: The Knife's first album in seven years is the Swedish duo's most political, ambitious, accomplished album, but in a strange way it also feels like its most personal, a musical manifesto advocating for a better, fairer, weirder world.

title: Caveman
label: Fat Possum
description: Following 2011's CoCo Beware, the N.Y. five-piece Caveman have tweaked their folksy template, embracing the spacey expanses and mournful, low-key melodies only hinted at on their debut.

title: I Hear a New World
label: PoppyDisc
description: In 1959, a couple years after Sputnik 1 was launched into orbit, the eccentric London audio engineer Joe Meek attempted “to create a picture in music of what could be up there in outer space.” With the release of this vinyl reissue more than 50 years later, I Hear a New World still sounds surreal, an alternate universe that infiltrated our own.

title: Victim of Love
label: Dunham
description: The soul singer's second album for Daptone finds him in a more optimistic mood, channeling the sound of 1970s greats like Al Green and Curtis Mayfield, and the sheer power of his voice is undiminished.

title: Cold
label: Hippos in Tanks
description: James Ferraro's lastest stylistic turn finds him taking on beguiling electronic body music that is heavily informed by commercial R&B and hip-hop but that somehow remains in his own bizarre soundworld.

title: Totale Nite
label: Night People
description: Merchandise aren't the first band to draw inspiration from 80s mope rock, but the Tampa, Fla., group's background in the hardcore and DIY community has given them an edge on your average gang of 20-something miserablists. On their latest LP*,* they tighten up their blend of weirdo tones and emo conviction.

title: Time EP
label: Captured Tracks
description: Alex Calder is a 23-year-old musician who previously played drums in Mac DeMarco's shaggy band Makeout Videotape; on his debut EP, he sounds very much like a kindered spirit and puts his own spin on DeMarco's clever slacker jams.

title: Abandon All Life
label: Southern Lord
description: Nails cram their brief but constantly shifting tracks with a chaotic, complex blend of hardcore punk, D-Beat, grindcore, powerviolence, and death metal. It's music that plows ahead while moving in dozens of different directions.

title: snakes/vultures/sulfate
label: Riot House
description: Best known as the drummer for Interpol, Sam Fogarino's solo album as a singer-songwriter has, at best, a white-knuckle grasp on competency. It features the Jesus Lizard's Duane Denison and former Secret Machine Brandon Curtis, but little of what distinguishes them as players.

title: rkives
label: Little Record Company
description: The rarities set rkives is a full-sounding collection that reads like a long-lost Rilo Kiley album from the early-2000s, a fact that will satisfy the many fans maddened by their late-career stab at the mainstream, Under the Blacklight.

title: The Terror
label: Bella Union
description: The Flaming Lips' unrelenting new album retains Embryonic's weighty mood but deconstructs the instrumental bombast into skeletal, mechanical forms. Where its 2009 antecedent played on themes of environmental destruction, The Terror deals in personal turmoil-- loneliness, depression, and anxiety.

title: Cosy Moments
label: Kill Rock Stars
description: Kinski's last album, Down Below It’s Chaos, featured a band that sounded like it was trying to escape its own skin. Their latest, Cosy Moments, doubles down on Down Below’s shift to hard rock, sounding at times like it was made in the band’s hometown of Seattle about 22 years ago.

title: Lil Ghetto Boy
label: Jet Life
description: With a few exceptions, the only alumnus of heyday-era No Limit who’s been consistently releasing worthwhile music is New Orleans' Fiend. With Lil Ghetto Boy, his first tape of the year, he serves up a satisfying slab of weed-rap that supercedes even 2011’s excellent Tennis Shoes & Tuxedos.

title: Tales from Terra Firma
label: 4AD
description: The Oxford folk pop band are still clearly in love with traditional Celtic and British music on their second album, but struggle to match the vital catchiness of their source material.

title: Machineries of Joy
label: Rough Trade
description: The Cumbrian band's sixth album sees British Sea Power growing more comfortable with their niche as Britain's most comprehensive purveyors of grandiose, yet compact rock songs filled with arcane literary and historical references.

title: Vanishing Point
label: Sub Pop
description: Vanishing Point is the first Mudhoney album in five years, and Steve Turner's erratic soloing, Dan Peters' hyperactive drum fills, and Mark Arm's righteous middle-aged rancor are so defiantly Mudhoney-sounding that they justify the price of admission.

title: 1017 Thug
label: Unknown
description: Atlanta rapper Young Thug marries the hook-bending sensibility of Future, the pill-addled yawp of Danny Brown, and the playful irreverance of Lil B with the guiding aura of Lil Wayne's experimental period. When he finds the right balance on 1017 Thug, it makes for some of the best, most fun-loving rap of the year.

title: Update
label: Hotflush
description: Paul Rose has proven one of dance music's most inventive producers, someone who takes bass places it rarely frequents. This digital-only compilation cherrypicks highlights from his Scuba project's seven-year existence, abandoning chronology in favor of something approaching a narrative.

title: The Ascent
label: Warner Bros.
description: The British rapper Wiley’s career seems to seesaw between rough-hewn respectability and goofy populism. The Ascent, his latest sweep into the second category, bows to the received wisdom of cramming as many guest artists, producers and stylistic tics as humanly possible into a 50-minute listen.

title: Indigo Meadow
label: Blue Horizon
description: Ever inspired by the 1960s, the Texan psych rockers' latest album sees them veer away from the influence of the Velvet Underground toward the Yardbirds and the sound of Nuggets. The results are pseudo-menacing, flower-power-corny, and rather anachronistic.

title: Change Becomes Us
label: Pinkflag
description: For their tenth album, the great British art punk band returns to the material that they would have recorded for the album that never ended up following 154, their third LP. Originally heard in muddy, difficult live recordings, the 13 songs on Change Becomes Us sparkle.

title: Until In Excess, Imperceptible UFO
label: Jagjaguwar
description: The Besnard Lakes’ husband/wife team of Jace Lasek and Olga Gorea aren’t just songwriters who produce pop tunes; they're composers who create musical suites out of sweepingly melodic movements. Their fourth album is their most “composed” to date.

title: Ride Your Heart
label: Dead Oceans
description: Best known as veterans of the beloved, defunct L.A. punk band Mika Miko, Jennifer and Jessica Clavin's new Shangri-Las-inspired project has the incisive, live-feeling production that their alma mater needed, but never quite had on record.

title: Haw
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: The songs on M.C. Taylor's fourth album as Hiss Golden Messenger pose questions about spiritual doubt rather than offer the easy reassurances familiar to rousing, populist folk rock. He draws from traditional Piedmont music as well as AM Gold country, jazz, rock, and pop.

title: Above (Deluxe Edition)
label: Columbia Legacy
description: This reissue of the Pearl Jam/Screaming Trees/Alice in Chains side-project's sole album is largely notable as a reminder of how this bewilderingly self-absorbed record may have killed off grunge.

title: Wolf
label: Odd Future
description: Two years after Goblin, the Odd Future ringleader returns with an album heavy on gorgeous beats and a lyrical focus that takes aim at the band's critics and the trappings of fame.

title: Heza
label: Polyvinyl
description: Generationals' third full-length takes their knack for writing bright, melodically-charged pop songs, but tones down the boisterousness of its predecessor, their 2011 high-water mark, Actor-Caster.

title: The Empire Never Ended
label: Dutty Artz
description: Matt Shadetek co-founded Brooklyn’s Dutty Artz collective with DJ/rupture. The label's regarded as an educator in global beats and dance culture, but on The Empire Never Ended, Shadetek puts aside his wide-cast net to release a collection of hip-hop instrumentals, one featuring a Riff Raff cameo.

title: Seabed
label: R&S
description: The UK R&B trio Vondelpark mix indie-pop vulnerability with sonic luxuriance. Arriving after a couple of EPs, their debut LP is the fullest realization of the project's immersive smoothness.

title: The Alchemist: The Best of Goldie 1992-2012
label: FFRR
description: There was a point in the late 90s where it looked like Clifford Price, aka Goldie, might be the first dance music artist to become a full-on mainstream megastar. The two discs of the new anthology The Alchemist: The Best Of Goldie 1992-2012 covering the span of Price’s career make a compelling argument that the world may finally be ready for him.

title: I Am Not a Human Being II
label: Young Money Entertainment
description: The possibility that Lil Wayne's new album could be overshadowed by his recent health scare is confirmed by this rote, crass reassembly of what once made him great. Weezy called II "my bum-ass album" on his release from hospital: turns out he wasn't just being self-deprecating.

title: The Devil's Dream: Alan Lomax's 1942 Library of Congress Recordings
label: Global Jukebox
description: The first release of the sole album by Senatobia's Sid Hemphill, the so-called "boar-hog musician of the hills," comes over 70 years after Alan Lomax first captured it on acetate. It's an extraordinary, strange, vehement collection that showcases Hemphill's singular yawp and absurd, infectious sense of humor.

title: Nostalchic
label: Brainfeeder
description: Lapalux stands out as one of the more accessible producers on Flying Lotus’s Brainfeeder label. On his debut album Nostalchic, Stuart Howard moves from deconstructed pop to a more relaxed brand of R&B and soul, both genres that complement his consistent interest in texture.

title: Dormarion
label: Merge
description: For his third Telekinesis record, Michael Benjamin Lerner traded in producer Chris Walla for Spoon’s Jim Eno, and Dormarion's power pop is grander and tougher than Lerner's past material.

title: The Julius Eastman Memory Depot
label: New Amsterdam
description: Jace Clayton, better and more-often known as DJ/rupture, pays tribute to a pioneering figure in minimalism and an influential member of the 1980s Downtown New York scene.

title: Delta Machine
label: Mute
description: Depeche Mode's thirteenth album sounds like it could be a set of outtakes from 1993's Songs of Faith and Devotion. On Delta Machine, they don't even bother pretending technology has opened up any possibilities for recorded sound in the past 20 years.

title: Dragged Down a Dead End Path
label: Relapse
description: Like their peers in Early Graves and the now-deceased Gaza, Call of the Void traffic in a hybrid of hardcore, death metal, and crust; they're not so much interested in melody as they are with laying waste.

title: Culture of Pink
label: Hands in the Dark
description: The reggae-ish guitar, dub-like bass, and deep-end beats on Cankun's Culture of Pink have a lot in common with Sun Araw's gripping grooves. They're engulfed by a sweaty, tropical fog, though remain remarkably attention-grabbing thanks to Vincent Caylet's knack for arrangements.

title: Understated
label: AED
description: 2010's Losing Sleep was the former Orange Juice frontman's first release since suffering cerebral hemorrhages in 2005. Understated's predominant lyrical theme is one of triumphant return, and the album feels like a crucial step towards Collins rediscovering his muse.

title: NoYork!
label: New World Color
description: Los Angeles rapper Blu's career trajectory runs counter to that of an artist working to infiltrate hip-hop’s mainstream. NoYork!, a mysterious album that first circulated two years ago, has gradually developed an underground following and now gets a physical release.

title: Amygdala
label: Pampa
description: Stefan Kozalla's first original solo album in nine years, featuring contributions from Caribou, Matthew Dear, and more, is uncommonly engrossing for a techno record. Blessed with the carefree spirit of lounge music and Quiet Storm, and dressed up in tiedye, the music on Amygdala glows with an easy confidence.

title: Love & Devotion
label: Planet Mu
description: The debut release by Planet Mu boss Mike Paradinas and his wife Lara Rix-Martin is nothing like Paradinas' work as µ-ziq. Instead they synthesize warm, romantic pop a la Fleetwood Mac with somber, technological anxiety, and the inherently sad vocals of Gravenhurst's Nick Talbot.

title: Make Memories
label: Northern Spy
description: On the L.A. quartet's first album since 2009's Anti-Magic, Foot Village has loosened the thematic concepts of their past work, though the group's trademark anthemic chants, strident declarations, and cryptic slogans remain intact among abstract, expansive swelling textures.

title: Wooden Ball
label: NNA Tapes
description: The latest in a rapid-fire series of releases from Vermont's Sarah Smith and Zach Phillips refines the Ariel Pink-inspired cheap speed world of last year's Wink With Both Eyes, developing their synthy skittishness in a way that recalls Devo's earliest albums.

title: 20 Jahre Kompakt / Kollektion 1
label: Kompakt
description: Once-seminal Cologne techno label Kompakt has, in part, sustained its 20-year existence through frequent compilation releases. The two-decade commemorative 20 Jahre Kompakt Kollektion isn't a greatest hits package, but a combination of defining songs and sentimental favorites.

title: Afraid of Heights
label: Mom & Pop
description: Afraid of Heights is the proper full-length follow-up to Wavves' 2010 breakthrough King of the Beach*.* Working with producer John Hill, it's Nathan Williams' best-sounding album to date, with touches of strings and background vocals from Jenny Lewis.

title: Meir
label: Roadrunner
description: The Norwegian band's second album, produced by Converge's Kurt Ballou and featuring cover art from Baroness' John Baizley, is their first for Warner subsidiary Roadrunner.

title: Off the Record
label: Bureau B
description: Off the Record is only the second album onetime Kraftwerk member Karl Bartos has made under his own name, and it's primarily based around music he recorded long ago, gathered from the vaults and given a 21st century gleam.

title: Miami
label: K7
description: On 2011's Mr. Machine, the Berlin group shifted their focus away from acoustic techno towards the concert hall, roping in a 10-piece orchestral ensemble. With the semi-conceptual Miami, they return to muscular sub-bass, booming kickdrums, and muscular, ominous arrangements.

title: Recover EP
label: Glassnote
description: The Glasgow trio's debut EP shows off Chvrches' penchant for exploring and embracing synth pop's artificial sunlight. The songs here are driven by themes of belief, devotion, and discovery, and imbued with an unabashed sense of wonder.

title: Comedown Machine
label: RCA
description: The Strokes' fifth album is more immediately appealing than their last two records as they sound like they’re genuinely trying here, and having fun. At times it feels like a mixtape the Strokes made for themselves: 11 songs, 11 different genre experiments.

title: Calidostópia!
label: self-released
description: The result of a 10-day recording session in Salvador De Bahia in Brazil, Calidostopia! features material from Oval's post-2010 output transformed into pop-structured songs featuring vocals from seven South American artists.

title: Ensemble Pearl
label: Drag City
description: Given that Ensemble Pearl features members of Sunn O))), Boris, and Jesse Sykes & the Sweet Hereafter, it's a surprise that their six-song debut sounds so elegant and subdued. But it's a testament to the plasticity of the musicians who made it, rather than their potential combined power.

title: Lady
label: Truth & Soul
description: Lady is a new Transatlantic collaboration between Atlanta's Nicole Wray and London's Terri Walker, who both experienced minor success at the turn of the century. Truth and Soul's production draws liberally on Motown and MFSB disco, and lets the singers' personalities shine through.

title: Impossible Truth
label: Merge
description: The Nashville-based William Tyler's second album for solo guitar in three years offers a lovely, rangy meditation on open-string drones, though Tyler has an uncommon way of making tangles of picked notes ring out like the melody of a searching pop song.

title: Bloodsports
label: Suede Limited
description: On Suede's first post-reunion album, Bernard Butler remains absent, but his replacement, Richard Oakes, has an undeniably reinvigorating effect on frontman Brett Anderson. His lyrics strike the balance between decadence and elegance, and seek meaningful, one-on-one connections.

title: The New Life
label: Slumberland
description: The second album by Belfast's Girls Names sees them shed the morbid C86 bent of their debut, opting instead for a turn towards post-punk's dreamier, more spectral corners.

title: Life After Defo
label: Cooperative
description: London producer/singer-songwriter Daniel Woolhouse became known through a Mariah Carey tribute, and his icy debut LP focuses on glimmering organs, stuttering percussion, harp sounds, and digitized Bon Iver-style vocal swoops.

title: Hit-Boy Presents HS87 – All I've Ever Dreamed Of
label: HS87
description: Hit-Boy has produced career-defining songs for Lil Wayne, Nicki Minaj, and Watch the Throne, but his solo material lacks personality. This first release from his new Interscope imprint is a compilation that presents the best of his, Kent M$NEY, K. Roosevelt, and Audio Push's respective skills.

title: Entrench
label: Season of Mist
description: A belligerent shot of heavy metal and hardcore, math rock and no wave*, Entrench* is the Winnipeg band KEN mode's fifth album in 10 years, but the Matt Bayles-produced collection has the unbridled energy of a debut, down to frontman Jesse Matthewson's ferocious rants about idealism, middle-age, and religion.

title: The Invisible Way
label: Sub Pop
description: Jeff Tweedy produced the Duluth band's tenth studio album, placing an emphasis on the drama that distinguishes it from previous Low efforts. Alan Sparhawk and Mimi Parker sound like true equals here, as their writing, singing, and playing complement one another vividly.

title: Pretend To Be Brave
label: Magic Marker
description: Five albums into their career, Seattle's BOAT have carved out a niche in the crowded contemporary indie rock landscape by delivering tuneful power-pop with a sense of humor. Pretend to Be Brave, finds the group maintaining their finely honed sonic equilibrium while exploring new lyrical motifs.

title: The Stand-In
label: ATO
description: The Nashville singer-songwriter Caitlin Rose started out playing warehouse punk shows alongside bands like JEFF the Brotherhood. On her third album, featuring swooning pedal steel, twanging electric guitar, and ringing tube amps, she has some quibbles with the modern age.

title: Change the Beat: The Celluloid Records Story 1980 – 1987
label: Strut
description: The 1980s glory years of the little New York-via-Paris imprint Celluloid Records are celebrated on this compilation, which runs the gamut from experimental rock (Shockabilly, Snakefinger) to early hip-hop (Fab 5 Freddy, Grandmaster D.ST).

title: Superpowerless
label: Morr
description: As bassist for Yo La Tengo since 1992, James McNew's songwriting eventually got absorbed into his main band's output. But his first two solo albums as Dump, reissued here, are modest, fuzzy records that lovingly represent the loser-happy indie pop rhetoric of his early 90s scene.

title: The Chronicles of Marnia
label: Kill Rock Stars
description: Marnie Stern's fourth album is an extension of the transition that began on her 2010 self-titled record toward a more controlled, subdued sound. Marnia is still aggressive, busy, and bright, but new drummer Kid Millions gives it a welcome sway, and the relative calm lets Stern's vulnerability shine through.

title: Sky Burial
label: Relapse
description: The second album by Inter Arma is a bleak picture of danger, apocalypse, despair, and dismay. But the Richmond, VA, band's energy and obvious enthusiasm for their unlikely alchemy of influences-- such as Zeppelin, Lightning Bolt, and Sleep-- make Sky Burial a truly exhilarating listen.

title: Water on Mars
label: Drag City
description: Purling Hiss started as the murky, fuzzed-out solo side-project of Mike Polizze, then the guitarist of Philadelphia free-form heavy rock outfit, Birds of Maya. War on Mars is the first record Polizze has done as part of a trio and also the first to be assembled in a professional studio.

title: The Patriarch
label: self-released
description: 25-year old NC rapper Deniro Farrar's voice falls somewhere between Bun B and former G-Unit great Young Buck. His second solo tape, featuring production from Ryan Hemsworth and Flosstradamas, finds him transcending the "blog-rap" tag.

title: Lines
label: Underwater Peoples
description: Four albums into his career, Julian Lynch continues to score deeper into his reputation for pristine arrangements, indecipherable lyrics, and swiftly curtailed genre explorations. Lines veers from dense folk to the lightly jazzy post-rock of Tortoise and the Sea and Cake.

title: The 20/20 Experience
label: RCA
description: On Justin Timberlake's first album in seven years, the pop superstar reunites with longtime producer/collaborator Timbaland for an album that seamlessly conflates the last 40 years of pop, soul, and R&B into a series of ambitious, long songs.

title: Hemp Is Here
label: Digitalis
description: This unusual recording was first released in 1985 and was rescued from obscurity by the Digitalis label. At times, it recalls future voyages into playfulness by artists like the Focus Group; elsewhere it exhibits a strong sense of junk shop experimentalism later shared by groups like Pram.

title: Via
label: Thrill Jockey
description: On Via, the former Come singer specializes in thorny songs that unflinchingly address adult topics and problems, with the malleable backing of her guitar and band providing either momentary refuge or sympathetic cries of exasperation.

title: Ripely Pine
label: Ba Da Bing!
description: The debut studio album from singer-songwriter Aly Spaltro is filled with bloody, body-focused epics that call to mind Jeff Buckley, Okkervil River, Jack White, Helium, and the Dirty Three.

label: Rough Trade
description: Palma Violets are a young band who've already received ecstatic acclaim from the most excitable parts of the English music press. They sound like rock music probably entered their lives with the Arctic Monkeys, and they’re still thrilled by it.

title: Muchacho
label: Dead Oceans
description: On Muchacho, Matthew Houck's sixth full-length as Phosphorescent, he gathers together everything he's attempted to date-- beery, rollicking country-rock, haunted tribal hymnals, regret-soaked bar room heartbreak-- and fashions it into something close to a defining statement.

title: Known Flood
label: Sacrament Music
description: This urgent instrumental album welds the power of black metal, sludge metal, and grindcore to the structures and orders of post-rock and post-punk.

title: Child Ballads
label: self-released
description: Child Ballads is a deceptively wispy collection of old English and Scottish folk songs, a collaboration sprouted a few years ago when Mitchell and Hamer discovered their shared fascination with the British folk canon established by a Harvard professor in the late 1800s.

title: Sock it to Me
label: Hardly Art
description: The songs on the L.A.-via-Boston grunge-popper's first full-length are brazenly simple, but they have a shrugging, take-me-as-I-am charm that makes them feel like celebrations of their own limitations, recalling Beat Happening, the Ramones, and Blink-182 before they briefly grew up.

title: The False Alarms
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: L.A.'s fractured pop collective returns with an album that at its best builds on the modest success of early single "In Ruins". Elsewhere, the band experiments with coldwave and trance-inducing new wave.

title: Free Reign II
label: Domino
description: Clinic asked Oneohtrix Point Never's Daniel Lopatin to mix their 2012 album, Free Reign, only to shelve all but two of his submissions. On this complete album overhaul, the Liverpool band reinstate Lopatin's mixes and rejig the sequencing to astonishing effect.

title: Who's That Man: A Tribute to Conny Plank
label: Grönland
description: This four-disc box set tribute to the man born Konrad Plank demonstrates how the Neu!, Can, and Eno collaborator transformed the producer role, and wholly altered the trajectories of German kosmische music, New Romanticism, and electro, along with many other genre fields.

title: The Plague of a Coming Age
label: Debemur Morti
description: The band led by Finland's M. Lehto continues to integrate nature-worshiping neo-folk with a harsher but still melodic mix of doom and black metal.

title: Invisible Life
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: Over the past few years, Roberto Carlos Lange has gone from making softly warped, pastoral music with Spanish lyrics and Latin influences to more urbane pop with bi-lingual lyrics. A sultry, dreamy temperament always remains, and Invisible Life is Helado Negro's clearest record yet.

title: All My Relations
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Black Pus is the pop-inspired side project of Lightning Bolt's Brian Chippendale-- but it's only "pop" in comparison to his main gig's Jackson Pollock-style approach. All My Relations is the first Black Pus album to be recorded in a professional studio, and proves less blown-out, and more sing-songy than its predecessors.

title: Spring Breakers OST
label: Atlantic
description: The soundtrack for Harmony Korine's new film features new and old tracks from Skrillex along with contributions from Cliff Martinez, and fills out the selection with songs by Waka Flocka Flame, Meek Mill, and Gucci Mane. The disparate parts work together surprisingly well.

title: Sleeper
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: Once a model who appeared on the covers of Vogue and Marie Claire, the singer's debut is the first music she's ever shared with the world, having written in private for years. Sleeper evokes the seedy prowl of Royal Trux and early Sonic Youth, and has a disaffected air.

title: The Deserters
label: Paper Bag
description: As half of Cat's Eyes with the Horrors' Faris Badwan, opera singer Rachel Zeffira sang smoochy girl-group songs through an orchestral, broken-radio haze. On her lavish solo debut, recorded in part at Abbey Road, she's a more spectral presence atop pillowy arrangements.

title: The G... The Growth & Development
label: Slow Motion Soundz
description: Following the dissolotuion of G-Side, rapper ST has stayed busy. Originally planned to be G-Side’s sixth LP, The G... The Growth & Development wound up as his full-length solo debut.

title: Adrian Younge Presents the Delfonics
label: Wax Poetics
description: Delfonics founding member and lead vocalist William Hart teams up with Adrian Younge for a surprisingly radical late-career record: Younge places Hart in a stylized version of the past that works as a tribute, deconstruction, and revamp of his band's once-vanguard Philly sound template.

title: Sound City: Real to Reel OST
label: Roswell
description: Dave Grohl's directorial debut, Sound City, pays tribute to the classic L.A. recording spot of the same name. For the soundtrack, he enlists musicians like Paul McCartney, Trent Reznor, Stevie Nicks, and Rick Springfield to cut an album at his studio.

title: Concrete Sustain
label: Seventh Rule
description: On their ambitious new album, the industrialized N.Y. metal band Batillus demonstrate their intention to shake loose the formulas of doom and stoner metal, breaking beyond the genre’s barriers, as well as their own.

title: Caustic View EP
label: Liberation Technologies
description: The promising 21-year-old UK producer follows last year's Hessle-released EP, Dust March, with an EP for Mute offshoot Liberation Technologies. His music frequently sounds as if it's being played back through an old Tascam that's been thrown down a few flights of stairs.

title: Grand Quarters
label: Decon
description: The Detroit rapper's new EP gathers some previously released Chuck-Inglish-produced tracks and adds newer material with more of a radio-friendly sheen, highlighting the versitality of James' style.

title: Honky Tonk
label: Rounder
description: Jay Farrar has always stood up for the Little Guy in America, regular folks facing down some challenge. But Son Volt's latest, Honky Tonk, shows the Little Guy at leisure, channeling the midtempo stylings of musicians like Buck Owens and Merle Haggard.

title: Mala
label: Nonesuch
description: Having eased back significantly since 2009's ambitious What Will We Be, Banhart draws from pre-Beatles concepts of pop and rock on Mala, and writes from distinctly non-punk perspectives such as loving with levity, and aging with grace.

title: Toy Love
label: Flying Nun
description: They existed for less than two years, but the Chris Knox-fronted post-punk band Toy Love are immeasurably important to New Zealand music. Goner's Live at the Gluepot is a ripping double LP of recordings from their final shows. And, as part of its reissue program with Flying Nun, Captured Tracks has compiled two discs’ worth of singles and demos.

title: LISm
label: Bpitch Control
description: Adapted from a work Allien produced for a dance performance at Paris' Pompidou Centre in 2011, LIsm is a single track that clocks in at 45 minutes. It's her most fractured work to date, veering from abstraction into song-oriented forms through the clubby territory that made her name.

title: Between Places
label: Modular
description: This Norwegian pop collective has toured with Tame Impala, and has a sound that touches on the Beach Boys and Veckatimest-era Grizzly Bear. Their music exalts the transformative power of imagination.

title: Krieg und Frieden (Music for Theatre)
label: Mute
description: The Berlin producer Apparat's Krieg und Frieden (Music for Theatre) was adapted from a score for German director Sebastian Hartmann's 2012 theatrical production of Tolstoy’s War and Peace. The result is a delightful challenge to both fixity and expectations.

title: The Next Day
label: ISO
description: On several levels, David Bowie's 24th studio album is a cunning act of sleight of hand. From the "Heroes"-referencing cover on down, he hasn't only come to terms with his past, he's making his old material work for his new material.

title: Golden Grrrls
label: Slumberland
description: The Glaswegian indie pop trio's full-length debut follows a series of 7-inch and cassette-only releases that presented Golden Grrrls' modest, pared-down charms in appropriately modest, pared-down packages.

title: Deathfix
label: Dischord
description: The influence of Big Star and Deep Purple looms large over the first collaborative album by Fugazi's Brendan Canty and singer-songwriter/remixer Rich Morel, who met as members of Bob Mould's touring band.

title: Punk Authority EP
label: Software
description: The trajectory of noise musician Pete Swanson's solo recordings is one of increased corrosion. But on his new collection, Punk Authority, he pulls everything into a bigger, fuller, more expansive framework.

title: Misogyny Drop Dead EP
label: Human Level
description: Janine Rostron's EP for International Women's Day trades her usual impressionistic lyrics for overt statements about the necessary death of the patriarchy. Accordingly, she also adapts her vocal style, coming off like tUnE-yArDs' Merrill Garbus in reggae-influenced mode.

title: New Moon
label: Sacred Bones
description: The Men's follow-up to 2011’s Leave Home and last year’s Open Your Heart is a deeper and more mature record steeped in rock signifers; it shows the difference between respecting tradition and being boring, between quieting down and going soft, between being earnest and being sappy.

title: Ores & Minerals
label: Fat Cat
description: The follow-up to the London band's 2011 debut still sounds like many of the 90s American indie bands lovingly mimicked on that album, but comes off more as a winningly idiosyncratic hybrid of their own making than an enthusiastic photocopy.

title: Girl Talk
label: have 10p
description: The English singer-songwriter returns with her third album. Working outside the major label system (she used crowd-sourced funding to make Girl Talk), Nash seems to be rebelling against her fame, switching things up musically and adopting a more confrontational tone.

title: Social Experiment 003
label: No. 19 Music
description: The Canadian house duo's buffed up, high-gloss DJ mix uses minor key melodies and densely layered rhythmic patterns to get across their persistent themes of desire, obsession, self-disgust, and fear of abandonment.

title: Mowgli
label: Lefse
description: The young Chicago producer Nick Zanca records home-schooled electronic music as Mister Lies. His buzzed-about debut full-length is an act of auditory hypnosis egged on by repetition and lush textures.

title: Cerulean Salt
label: Don Giovanni
description: Last year's American Weekend, Katie Crutchfield's piercing debut as Waxahatchee, got passed around like a secret. Cerulean Salt, Crutchfield's second album, demonstrates newfound assurance, marking her as a new songwriting voice to reckon with.

title: Passages Into Deformity
label: Willowtip
description: Striking a balance between blinding technicality and hardcore-style breakdowns, the German death metal quartet Defeated Sanity's fourth album includes piano, freeform drums, and macabre noise interludes not usually associated with the genre.

title: Images Du Futur
label: Secretly Canadian
description: On their second record, Montreal's Suuns mix the mechanical pulse of krautrock, post-punk's fractured syntax, and unorthodox instrumental techniques in a manner that brings to mind Clinic.

title: In Dark Denim
label: Greedhead
description: The buzzed-out San Jose rapper, who says thrash metal and Biohazard were the music of his youth, has rapped over Suzanne Vega and Goldfrapp samples. On his debut for Das Racist member Heems' Greedhead label, his personality is ahead of his artistry.

title: A Love Surreal
label: eOne
description: A Love Surreal is only Bilal's third studio album in 12 years. Its jazzy, muted, idiosyncratic feel, and a lack of big guest names, makes it seem like the personal project of someone who has embraced the ability to make music away from commercial expectations.

title: Welcome Oblivion
label: Columbia
description: Welcome Oblivion is the debut LP from How to destroy angels_, the project of Trent Reznor, his wife, singer Mariqueen Maandig, collaborator Atticus Ross, and visual artist Rob Sheridan. It mostly maintains the elliptical electronic approach of last year's An Omen EP_.

title: Needs Continuum
label: No Pain in Pop
description: London-based Midwestener Karen Gwyer recorded her debut album on No Pain is Pop while pregnant with her first child. The result, which recalls Oneohtrix Point Never and Julianna Barwick, is a loosely finished collection that feels like entering a deeply private realm.

title: Hi Beams
label: Luaka Bop
description: In the handful of years they've been making music together, pop collagists George Langford and Tom Van Buskirk have never been afraid to push their luck. Doing away with their trademark samples, the slick-sounding, candy-colored Hi Beams is their first real studio record.

title: The Beast in Its Tracks
label: Pytheas
description: The Idaho singer-songwriter's last two albums were less about himself and more about America and all its weird history. The Beast in Its Tracks, however, chronicles Ritter's split from his wife in 2010, observed with a cool distance and scaled-back arrangements.

title: Laid Out EP
label: Friends of Friends
description: Shlohmo is part of a new wave of producers who make use of every musical ingredient available to them; they source samples and influences from any decade, genre, or style that they’re interested in. His latest EP makes brilliant use of vocal processing and has a guest spot from How to Dress Well.

title: Woman
label: Republic
description: Rhye is the project of singer/producer Mike Milosh and producer Robin Hannibal. Together, they make ethereal R&B focusing on world-tilting romantic experience, with gorgeous minimal production that leaves little space between the listener and the songs.

title: Askel Lähempänä Saatanaa
label: World Terror Committee
description: On their first album in five years, the legendary Finnish black metal band showcase their reverence for black metal's Second Wave as well as their deft utilization of melody within their jagged, apocalyptic compositions.

title: Hymnal
label: Kranky
description: As Benoît Pioulard, UK-via-Mich. multi-instrumentalist Thomas Meluch comes across as a doomed romantic slowly disappearing into his own reflection. His newest collection, which culminates in an imposing drone piece, was inspired by the religious iconography of Southern England and mainland Europe.

title: Untogether
label: Arbutus
description: Following their excellent, sun-kissed 2010 EP Blooming Summer, the Montreal electro pop duo of Alexander Cowan and Braids' Raphaelle Standell-Preston release a chillier full-length focused on themes of disconnect, alienation, and independence.

title: Trust EP
label: Ghostly
description: Three years on from Lucky Shiner and following his DJ-Kicks set, the new EP from Gold Panda finds him refining his approach and exploring familiar themes, mixing bell-like textures, slow-mo house, and foggy drone.

title: Wondrous Bughouse
label: Fat Possum
description: Youth Lagoon follows his heartfelt 2011 debut The Year of Hibernation with an album that is bigger, bolder, and more emotionally resonant, thanks to production from Ben Allen. Trevor Powers' project is firmly in the lineage of bands like Mercury Rev, Sparklehorse, and Modest Mouse.

title: Die zauberhafte Welt der Anderen
label: Kompakt
description: The title of the latest collaboration between brothers Wolfgang and Reinhard Voigt translates as "The Magical World of Others". It's less the straightforward collection of minimal techno you'd expect from them than an immersion into a strange universe that may or may not tell a story.

title: Selected Studies, Vol. 1
label: Bureau B
description: For Selected Studies, Vol. 1, the prolific krautrock elder statesman Hans-Joachim Roedelius collaborated with the bookish singer-songwriter Lloyd Cole by exchanging files online.

title: Cyclopean EP
label: Mute
description: The debut EP from Can co-founders Irmin Schmidt and Jaki Liebezeit and collaborators Jono Podmore and Burnt Friedman represents a phase of sonic mastery for these four innovators, rather than outright experimentation. Cyclopean is a crisp, seamless set.

title: Somewhere Else
label: Paper Bag
description: Somewhere Else isn't quite a departure from Sally Shapiro's last two albums, but in among the sequencers and identikit drums are instruments from a more muted palette: flute, saxophone, and beats that skitter rather than shimmer.

title: Chelsea Light Moving
label: Matador
description: With Sonic Youth drifting into an unofficial, maybe-permanent hiatus, Thurston Moore has started a louder, younger rock band featuring Samara Lubelski and members of Hush Arbors and Sunburned Hand of the Man. Their self-titled debut is the heaviest, most dissonant music Moore's put together in recent memory.

title: Privilege
label: Slender Means Society
description: On Parenthetical Girls' fourth album, the Portland indie-pop band's first since 2008, leader Zach Pennington plays the part of the amoral schoolboy fated to be caught in bed in a scandalous tryst with the headmistress or -master.

title: Homosapien
label: Felte
description: The Australian band explores a vast array of electronics-enhanced pop influences on their third album, their first to feature frontman Richard Pike's vocals on every song. It's just one aspect of an extensive band overhaul that's made them substantially more accessible.

title: Hello EP
label: Merok
description: The Montreal art pop artist's new EP makes good on Caila Thompson-Hannant's "bedroom paranoia" tag, bearing both a DIY pop aesthetic and a lyrical preoccupation with the anxieties of crushing, dating, and intimacy.

title: The Luca Brasi Story
label: Unknown
description: Louisiana rapper Kevin Gates is a star on par with Lil Boosie around his stomping grounds in Baton Rouge and New Orleans, but he hasn’t had much luck in popping nationally. His mixtapes peruse an emotive, melodic style that often gets him lumped into the same milieu as introspective lady-killers like Drake and Future.

title: Les Revenants
label: Rock Action
description: Mogwai's soundtrack to the French drama of the same name rarely comes off overly dramatic or leading. While the musical structures are often simple, continually recasting the central motif with xylophone, piano, and guitar, they push individual sounds to disquieting levels.

title: Heliosphere
label: 50 Weapons
description: Following last year's They!Live collaboration with Doc Daneeka, Welsh producer Benjamin Damage moves into the harsher, straightline industrial realm of rave techno for his first solo collection.

title: An A.merican D.ream
label: Mexican Summer
description: Michael Gerner's surrealist trad-rock group returns for An A.merican D.ream, a record enamored with the thrilling possibilities and tired clichés of classic rock.

title: The Complete Recorded Works in Chronological Order Volume 1
label: Third Man
description: Jack White's Third Man Records has started a program reissuing selections from the vault of Document Records, beginning with Charlie Patton, Blind Willie McTell, and the Mississippi Sheiks. While all are filled with excellent music, the reissues also afford an opporunity to discuss how and why reissue programs exist.

title: Outrun
label: Mercury
description: Kavinsky's "Nightcall" is almost as synonymous with Drive as Ryan Gosling. The French musician's new album isn't linked to a film, but centers around an automotive story of Kavinsky's creation, and replicates the soundtracks to 1980s driving video games with eerie accuracy.

title: Lesser Evil
label: Arbutus
description: The Canadian art-pop artist's debut album is as much a product of his time in Montreal and Toronto's DIY scenes as it is influenced by their predecessors in Brooklyn and Baltimore. But Lesser Evil is primarily rooted in Airick Woodhead's dystopian imagination.

title: Void
label: Jolly Dream
description: Featuring former Jay Reatard collaborator Ryan Rousseau, Arizona's Destruction Unit create an uneasy haze of dark psychedelics with Void's sprawling kraut rock and muscular punk.

title: Total Folklore
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Dan Friel's second solo album of blown-out, euphoric songs was made using cheap keyboards, chained pedals, field recordings, and knick-knacks. The precarious setup translates into punchy instrumentals instilled with raw energy, which doesn't stint on either side of the noise pop deal.

title: Optica
label: Merge
description: The Swedish band's fourth album is warm, expansive, and swimming in strings. The Shout Out Louds took their sweet time with Optica, and it shows.

title: Through the Window
label: Blackest Ever Black
description: Having taken a pleasurable detour toward grinding synth pop on his 2011 releases Bermuda Drain and Time's Arrow, with Through the Window, Dominick Fernow convincingly throws himself to the growling hounds of techno.

title: Anxiety
label: Mexican Summer
description: When Autre Ne Veut released his self-titled debut in 2010, his unwieldy, anonymous handle and approximations of 1980s and 90s R&B made him the epitome of a fringe concern. But Anxiety is a marvelous and moving second LP.

title: Velvet Changes
label: Carpark
description: Dog Bite is a dream pop project helmed by Washed Out sideman Phil Jones, who shares his other band's interest in billowy atmospheres and and gauzy layering.

title: The Underground Resistance
label: Peaceville
description: The Norwegian duo gave up on black metal a long time ago, turning instead to an open-ended interest in the metal they loved as kids: thrash and crust punk, high-flying British metal, and blustery hardcore. It's hard to imagine two middle-aged men having more fun than Darkthrone do on their propulsive sixteenth studio album.

title: New Jet City
label: Warner Bros.
